instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-01598: What is 820-01598? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01598</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-06 <CHIP>U7270</CHIP> gets hot
threads.message:
I'm working on a <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01598</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-06 that had liquid damage around <CHIP>U7270</CHIP> and <CHIP>U7210</CHIP> and was stacking at 5V. Liquid damage is cleaned.
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> had a short to ground with 13.7Ohm. The same value i measured at L7270. So i changed <CHIP>U7270</CHIP> and the Short was gone and i have 20V on the charger.
The problem now is that <CHIP>U7270</CHIP> gets real hot. The board takes something over 1A.

The original <CHIP>U7270</CHIP> on the board was an FDMF5812, the schematic shows an SIC532CD. I changed <CHIP>U7270</CHIP> now two times. The first time i took a SIC532CD from a donor. The second time i took a new SIC535 with same problem. 

I'm not very good in understanding mosfet circuits and need some help.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01598</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-06 <CHIP>U7270</CHIP> gets hot
threads.message:
Dead CPU most likely.
Overvolatge occured through <CHIP>U7270</CHIP>, at least.
